description: {"blocks":[{"key":"82mi","text":"This is the instructor protocol for the student Ligation protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":36,"length":30}],"data":{}},{"key":"c0ska","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edbrd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1uno","text":"The abstract for the student protocol explains the basics. I pre-digest the L2-01 backbone for my students, but I generally do not gel-purify it. I find that the ligation is generally pretty robust, with three caveats:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6l1rq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"djl57","text":"Because I don't gel-purify, we need to bias the ligation towards ligating the annealed oligos (not the GFP that was digested out). To do so, I dilute the backbone to 10 fmol/ul and instruct the students to dilute their annealed oligos to 200 fmol/ul (which is  ).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":260,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dcves","text":"Ligase is EXPENSIVE, and this kind of ligation does not need much -- so I dilute 1:5 into small tubes. Thus, if a beginning student screws something up (throws the tube away, or contaminates it, etc), the expensive master reagent tube isn't lost.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"m0pp","text":"The ligase buffer contains ATP, which is heat-labile. (When a ligation fails, it's often because the buffer is bad, not the enzyme!) Thawing and re-freezing is not good for it. So, I aliquot the ligase buffer into single-use 5 ul aliquots in PCR tubes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pb4c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E893347018D711ED871F3390B018EF91","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/ligation-5jyl89417v2w/v3"}},"1":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"200","error_concentration":false,"guid":"4FD6836014E811ED9AAF39C45E229303","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":30}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7dars","text":"At least 48 hours before the lab, strike out the L2-01 E. coli strain from a frozen stock on an LB+Kan plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fm8fb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efmrt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7n32b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d4sej","text":"Sanity check -- because the L2-01 plasmid has a GFP cassette, the colonies should be bright green!","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ba56u","text":"Instructor Tips","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3g39a","text":"The first step of the student protocol requires another dilution. Again, I'm hands-off for this one. A common student question is \"what is the concentration of my annealed oligos?\" and I suggest that they might be able to figure it out by reviewing the annealing protocol.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dt9mv","text":"I usually instruct students to run this protocol and the URA3 PCR protocol at the same time: set up the ligation, then while the ligation is incubating, set up their PCR.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8o5pd","text":"Common Student Errors","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32iir","text":"Omitting the dilution step (particularly if they need to retry the protocol.)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fek7g","text":"Small-volume pipetting.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2u3gd","text":"Optional: gel-purify the backbone. Run the entire miniprep on a preparative agarose gel, then use a kit such as the   to purify the larger band.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":132,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":116,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"11hlv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reagents","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":956775,"mol_weight":0,"name":"Monarch DNA Gel Extraction Kit","linfor":"","url":"https://www.neb.com/products/t1020-monarch-dna-gel-extraction-kit","sku":"T1020S","cas_number":"","rrid":"","public":1,"can_edit":0,"guid":"2152DC0014E811ED9AAF39C45E229303","in_steps":null,"vendor":{"id":2,"name":"New England Biolabs","link":"https://www.neb.com/","image":{"source":"/img/vendors/2.png","placeholder":"/img/vendors/2.png"}}}}}}

title: Ligation (Instructor Protocol)
warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"2lp3k","text":"Some components of the miniprep kit are hazardous; wear appropriate PPE.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fudv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qhes","text":"TE, oligos, ligase \u0026 buffer, etc. are not hazardous.  HOWEVER, we are shedding nucleases -- enzymes that degrade DNA -- all the time. Wear lab coats and gloves to keep your samples nuclease-free.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
